g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
ehavioural changes within transition pathways offer Gigaton
Individual motivation and capacity are impacted by different factors that go beyond traditional social,
demographic and economic predictors. However, it is unclear to what extent behavioural factors (i.e.,
aspects) are taken into account in policy design
hile economic policies play a significant role in influencing people’s
decisions and behaviour, many drivers of human behaviour and values work la
ctors in society, particularly individuals, do not

norms can be more quickly and more robustly shifted by proposing and framing
policies designed with awareness of how framings interact with individual cognitive tendencies
Transformative policies are thus much more likely to be successfully adopted
term behavioural change if designed in accordance with principles of cognitive
and benefits that take effect immediately than those delivered later

y positive discourses about economic, social, and cultural benefits of low
promises far more success than targeting mitigation alone
Climate actions are related to knowledge but even strongly to motivational factors
Bolderdijk et al. 2013; Boomsma and Steg 2014)
, which explains the gap between awareness and action
. Social influences, particularly from peers, affect people’s engagement in climate
. Role models appear to have a solid basis in people’s everyday preferences
. Social norms can reinforce individuals’ underlying motivations and be effective in
many examples offered by behavioural science
Collective action by individuals as part of formal social movements or informal lifestyle movements
individuals, but also become actors in their own right. Recent literature has considered the role of
coalitions and social movements in energy democracy and energy transitions towards sustainability
. Other scholars have examined the role of women in redistributing power, both in the
of energy transition and in terms of gender relations
